results.title: They Quit Their Jobs. Their Ex-Employers Sued Them for Training Costs.
results.abstract: Workers who sign training repayment agreements can owe their employers thousands of dollars if they leave their jobs early. Regulators are starting to crack down on the practice.

results.abstract: Senator Robert Menendez and his wife, Nadine, were freed after posting personal recognizance bonds. He can travel out of the country, but only on official business.

results.title: As Hundreds Were Celebrating a Wedding, It Turned Into an Inferno
results.abstract: As the bride and groom danced, witnesses said, flares were set off at the venue in northern Iraq, starting a fire that spread with astonishing speed and killed more than 100 people.

results.title: Baltimore Police Search for Suspect in Killing of Tech C.E.O.
results.abstract: Pava LaPere, 26, had been heralded in the city as a rising businesswoman devoted to her community. Officials said the suspect, a sex offender released from prison last fall, was armed and dangerous.

media.caption: Pava LaPere, 26, founder of EcoMap, a Baltimore tech start-up, was found dead on Monday.

results.abstract: Little more than three days before a government shutdown, the Republican-led House spent the day adding hard-right proposals to a series of doomed spending bills.

media.caption: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III has become a target of far-right Republicans. Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia declared that he “definitely deserves to be fired.”

results.byline: By Ilyssa Daly and Jerry Mitchell
results.title: The Sheriff, His Girlfriend and His Illegal Subpoenas
results.abstract: Powerful figures in Mississippi, including the attorney general, two judges and a future congressman, learned how a sheriff lied to spy on his girlfriend. They all kept his secret.

media.caption: Sheriff Bryan Bailey of Rankin County used the power of his office to subpoena the phone records of his girlfriend and another man she was reportedly seeing.

results.title: Senate Reaches Spending Deal to Head Off Government Shutdown
results.abstract: An agreement between Senate Republicans and Democrats would keep agencies open through mid-November and provide billions in aid for Ukraine and disaster relief. But House Republicans are likely to balk.
